april_21_2025_belief_focus_play_free.probleme: Mental pillars not in place during matches
april_21_2025_belief_focus_play_free.diagnostic: Hesitation and erratic play come from doubt, scattered attention, and conscious control during points.
causes_communes: Lack of self-belief before play begins
Mind cluttered with non-match thoughts
Trying to consciously control strokes mid-rally

debutant: Adopt BFF: Believe in yourself first; clear the mind; play freely.
Limit conscious thinking to simple tactics between points; during rallies, watch the ball and let training execute.
intermediaire: Build pre-point routines that reinforce belief and focus (breath, cue word) and trigger a 'play free' state at serve/receive.
avance: Train automaticity so subconscious handles execution under pressure; review between points only for concise tactical cues.

erreurs_a_eviter: Waiting to play well before believing
Thinking about mechanics during the point

meta.article_title: April 14, 2025 - Three Modes of Match Play - Serious, Practice, Beginner

april_14_2025_three_modes_of_match_play.probleme: Using the same approach for all opponent levels
april_14_2025_three_modes_of_match_play.diagnostic: Players either overuse tricks versus weak opponents or mentally let up and lose focus.
causes_communes: Throwing every tricky serve at non-threatening opponents
Letting up mentally once ahead

debutant: Versus competitive or stronger opponents: use best winning tactics.
Versus moderate opponents: after confirming dominance, use the match to practice core patterns while keeping full focus.
intermediaire: Rotate serves/plays that build skills you’ll need later; retain tricky serves as a fallback if trouble arises.
Optionally push/block more to conserve energy, or practice serves while maintaining point-by-point focus.
avance: Versus beginners: mostly rally to loosen up; occasionally show strong serves; maintain concentration throughout to prime next matches.

erreurs_a_eviter: Mentally letting up and losing focus spiral
Over-relying on trick serves when practice would prepare you better

meta.article_title: April 7, 2025 – How to Come Back from Down 0-2 in a Match

april_7_2025_come_back_from_down_0_2.diagnostic: Score reflects losing tactical patterns or malfunctioning shots.
causes_communes: Staying in losing rally types (e.g., backhand-to-backhand) without adjustment
Ignoring simple tactical shifts (e.g., attacking the middle)

debutant: Ignore the score; focus on performance for the next point only.
Identify what the opponent is winning on and change it to what you are winning on.
intermediaire: If losing a rally type, either avoid it (tactics) or deliberately enter it with intent to play it better if required to win.
Use simple, high-payoff adjustments (e.g., attack the elbow).
avance: Prevent future 0–2 holes by scouting and having a game plan; warm up properly; stay clear-minded.

erreurs_a_eviter: Obsessing over the score instead of causes
Overcomplicating the comeback plan

march_31_2025_study_opponents_serves.probleme: Slow adjustment to a new opponent’s serve
march_31_2025_study_opponents_serves.diagnostic: Players often spend a game learning serves instead of preparing beforehand.
causes_communes: Not scouting live or on video
Not simulating receive while watching

debutant: Before matches, watch upcoming opponents with a focus on their serves; imagine receiving as you watch.
intermediaire: If live, watch from directly behind the receiver to match the view; rehearse the receive motion.
avance: Create a pre-event list of likely opponents and study their serves so game one isn’t spent adjusting.

erreurs_a_eviter: Going into matches without a receive plan

meta.article_title: March 24, 2025 – Your Racket Is Your Musical Instrument

march_24_2025_your_racket_is_musical_ins.probleme: Trying to consciously control play during rallies
march_24_2025_your_racket_is_musical_ins.diagnostic: Execution suffers when conscious mind micromanages strokes instead of subconscious habits.
causes_communes: Overthinking mechanics mid-point
Not trusting trained reactions

debutant: Let subconscious run rallies; keep conscious mind on simple tactics and watching ball/opponent.
intermediaire: Use analogies (tying shoes, playing music) to reinforce automaticity; practice to build reliable triggers.
avance: Design routines that cue subconscious execution under pressure; review tactics only between points.

erreurs_a_eviter: Deciding each 'note' during play instead of reacting

march_17_2025_playing_the_weird_style.probleme: Difficulty versus uncommon styles or equipment
march_17_2025_playing_the_weird_style.diagnostic: Avoidance prevents subconscious adaptation; weird styles have inherent weaknesses.
causes_communes: Fearing mistakes and avoiding practice versus rare styles
Reacting robotically to unusual spins/trajectories

debutant: Play into the 'weird' elements until comfortable; expect a few extra errors and don’t get discouraged.
intermediaire: Target built-in weaknesses (e.g., give no-spin to long pips to get no-spin back and attack).
avance: Regularly practice against all surfaces (long/medium/short pips, antispin, hardbat) to build flexible reactions.

erreurs_a_eviter: Avoiding rare styles and staying unprepared
Treating them as unbeatable rather than exploitable

meta.article_title: March 10, 2025 - Where to Contact a Push

march_10_2025_where_to_contact_a_push.diagnostic: Contacting at top of bounce tends to pop the ball; rise or drop each have specific trade-offs.
causes_communes: Defaulting to top-of-bounce contact for convenience
Not exploiting on-the-rise or on-the-drop advantages

debutant: Prefer taking pushes on the rise to rush opponent and create angles when you can get there.
If late, take on the drop for maximum control and heavier spin.
intermediaire: Avoid routine top-of-bounce contacts that float; use only if aggressively driving the push with control.
avance: Blend rise and drop timing situationally for angle, depth, and spin control.

erreurs_a_eviter: Routinely pushing at the top of the bounce and giving easy attacks

meta.article_title: March 3, 2025 - Contact the Bottom of the Ball When Serving Backspin

march_3_2025_contact_bottom_of_ball_serv.diagnostic: Grazing toward the back forces downward hit or reduced spin.
causes_communes: Contacting too far back on the ball
Slowing stroke for control instead of accelerating with fine graze

debutant: Contact near the bottom of the ball (scooping feel) while accelerating the racket to produce heavy, short backspin.
intermediaire: Expect a 'struggle' to clear the net; use this as feedback that you’re creating heavy spin with minimal downward motion.
avance: Refine touch so serves barely clear the net and may stop or bounce backward on the far side.

erreurs_a_eviter: Reducing racket speed to gain control
Aiming contact too far back on the ball

meta.article_title: February 24, 2025 – Eight Quick Tips for Quicker Footwork

february_24_2025_eight_tips_quicker_foot.diagnostic: Equipment, stance, balance, and mindset limit first-step speed and recovery.
causes_communes: Loose or non-table-tennis shoes; slippery floors
Narrow stance and poor ready position
Weak recovery/positioning habits and balance
Lack of a pre-contact hop and mental readiness

debutant: Wear proper, tight table-tennis shoes; improve traction (new shoes, wet towel on slippery floors).
Adopt ready position with weight on outside balls of feet, knees slightly bent, slight forward lean.
intermediaire: Recover and reposition after each shot based on opponent’s angle; prioritize balance.
Add a small hop just before opponent contact to drop into a reactive crouch.
avance: Use confident self-cues (e.g., 'moving machine') to prime quick reactions.

erreurs_a_eviter: Staying off-balance between shots
Skipping the pre-contact hop

meta.article_title: February 17, 2025 – Forehand-Backhand Grip Changes and Learning New Techniques

february_17_2025_forehand_backhand_grip_.probleme: One fixed grip limits one wing (often the backhand)
february_17_2025_forehand_backhand_grip_.diagnostic: Historic belief against grip changes reduced backhand attack quality.
causes_communes: Using forehand-biased grip for both sides
Skipping the progression to automate grip switches

debutant: Find the perfect forehand grip; then find the perfect backhand grip (thumb pressure and slight top rotation away).
intermediaire: Practice the grip change repeatedly off-table and in shadow swings until natural; then in alternating FH–BH drills.
avance: Do random FH/BH drills and play matches until grip switches are automatic versus unfamiliar opponents; apply same progression to any new technique.

erreurs_a_eviter: Relying on one grip despite weakening a wing
Jumping into matches without automating the change

meta.article_title: February 10, 2025 - Why Are You Attacking Heavy Backspin Into the Net?

february_10_2025_attacking_heavy_backspi.probleme: Attacks on heavy backspin go into the net
february_10_2025_attacking_heavy_backspi.diagnostic: Average net clearance too low; shots not arced/deep enough to compensate for spin.
causes_communes: Insufficient racket opening or upward path
Aiming short rather than deeper to force a higher arc

debutant: Increase net clearance (or aim deeper) and rely on topspin to bring the ball down.
intermediaire: Video a match to audit miss distribution (net vs long vs in) and adjust to reduce into-net errors even if some go long.
avance: Calibrate arc and depth so more attacks land deep and on the table against heavy backspin.

metriques_progression: Track percentages: into-net vs off-end vs on-table on heavy-backspin attacks; aim for fewer into-net misses.
erreurs_a_eviter: Forcing low-clearance shots that dive into the net

meta.article_title: February 3, 2025 - Tactical Observations for the Subconscious

february_3_2025_tactical_obs_for_subcons.probleme: Late reactions due to watching only at contact
february_3_2025_tactical_obs_for_subcons.diagnostic: Subconscious can learn early cues (e.g., shoulder rotation) if you repeatedly observe them.
causes_communes: Relying on post-contact trajectory reading
Not training attention on pre-contact cues

debutant: Make a habit of observing opponents for early directional tells; let repetition train the subconscious.
intermediaire: React as the forward swing starts by reading the line from racket to ball; adjust for each player’s disguises.
avance: At higher levels, read shoulders/rotation even before swing; update timing per opponent as the match progresses.

erreurs_a_eviter: Expecting 'reflexes' without training early recognition

meta.article_title: January 27, 2025 - Do You Serve a Lot of Net Serves? Good!!!

january_27_2025_lot_of_net_serves_good.probleme: Serves are too high due to excess net clearance
january_27_2025_lot_of_net_serves_good.diagnostic: Few or no net (let) serves indicate serves are not low enough.
causes_communes: Serving with comfortable clearance instead of calibrating to skim the net

debutant: Practice low, short, spinny serves aiming to barely clear the net; accept occasional net lets as a good sign.
intermediaire: Calibrate depth and height so you can also serve deep and aggressive without fear of long faults.
avance: Use a box of balls and purposefully try to nick the net to find the lowest reliable trajectory.

exercices_complementaires.description: Serve 20 low, short, spinny serves trying to just brush the net while still clearing it; note how many are let serves without serving into the net.

metriques_progression: Count net (let) serves out of 20 without actual into-net faults.
erreurs_a_eviter: Pride in never nicking the net, signaling serves are too high
